On 2002-09-09 at 12:13 Jonathan Gossage wrote:

>----- Original Message -----
>From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>

>Sent: Monday, September 09, 2002 11:50 AM
>Subject: Re: [junit] test cases for inputs from file
>
>
>> My concurrency knowledge is less than it should be. Could you
provide
>> sample code for this? I assume you meant this:
>>
>> class MyTestFixture extends TestCase
>> setUp:
>> synchronized (MyTestFixture.class) {
>> // set up code
>> }
>>
>> tearDown:
>> synchronized (MyTestFixture.class) {
>> // tear down code
>> }
>>
>> testX:
>> synchronized (MyTestFixture.class) {
>> // test code
>> }
>>
>> Thanks.
>
>Exactly. Since Junit runs each test in an independent thread and runs
the
>setUp() and tearDown() methods in the main thread this ensres that
>everything is synchronized and that tests do not stomp on each other.
>
>
>>
>>
>> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>>
>> On 2002-09-09 at 08:27 Jonathan Gossage wrote:
>>
>> >----- Original Message -----
>> >From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
>> >To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
>> >Sent: Sunday, September 08, 2002 11:14 AM
>> >Subject: Re: [junit] test cases for inputs from file
>> >
>> >
>> >> On a number of occasions I have written a TestCase where setUp()
>> >> creates an object that uses the file system and tearDown() clears
>> the
>> >> entire tree used by that object. I have never successfully had
>> >> tearDown() finish before setUp() started for the next test, owing
to
>> >> the fact (I suppose) that the JVM does not block on the system
call.
>> >>
>> >> I ended up doing what you suggest: I use a different root
directory
>> for
>> >> each test, usually calling it something like
>> >>
>> >> root-<testClassName>-<testName>
>> >>
>> >> I then add a shutdown hook to clean them all up.
>> >
>> >I have a similar test situation where I am testing agasinst a smart
>> card
>> >and
>> >my solution
>> >was to synchronize on my test fixture in setUp(), tearDown() and
each
>> test
>> >case. This ensured that my tests ran synchronously and that the
smart
>> card
>> >was properly cleaned up before the next test started.
>> >
>> >>
>> >> Has anyone used Prevayler? If so, have you come up with any
>> strategies
>> >> for unit testing against the Prevayler without changing its
source?
>> I
>> >> have been considering refactoring Prevayler to talk to byte
streams
>> and
>> >> having one wrapper around it that uses the file system for
>> production
>> >> and another wrapper that keeps everything in memory for test.
>> >>
>> >> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
>> >>
>> >> On 2002-09-07 at 17:37 Andrew Forward wrote:
>> >>
>> >> >I am curious under what circumstances the file ssytem is too
slow
>> to
>> >> >clean up after itself?
>> >> >
>> >> >I have some code that crawls files and directories, so to test
this
>> >> >functionality I create the hierachy right in the TestCase. I
use a
>> >> >special createFile(...) method to, of course, create the file,
as
>> well
>> >> as
>> >> >track it in a Vector to be cleaned up on every tearDown();
>> >> >
>> >> >Would it be better to increment the root directory name and then
>> >> delete
>> >> >all the structures at the end of all test cases? Or would this
>> >> present a
>> >> >similar problem when joining multiple tests from multiple test
>> classes
>> >> >(provided they also access the file system in a similar manner).
>> >> >
>> >> >andrew f
>> >> >
>> >> >```````````````````````
>> >> >A common idea is to kill a folder on the file system after every
>> test,
>> >> in
>> >> >order to start with a "clean slate". Unfortunately, the
>> >> >tests are too fast for the file system, so the file system isn't
>> clean
>> >> >before the next test starts.
